snippet: The surpluses that many states are expecting this year are not as robust as they appear because of costs put off during the recession, like funding for Medicaid and pension systems.
abstract: Surpluses that many states are expecting this year are not as robust as they appear because of costs put off during the recession, like funding for Medicaid and pension systems;  surpluses have spurred debate in statehouses around the county, with some officials seeking to restore services and rehire workers, and others pushing new tax cuts; governors from both parties, though, find themselves urging restraint as their states climb back from the recession.

byline.original: By MICHAEL COOPER and MARY WILLIAMS WALSH

lead_paragraph: The surpluses that many states are expecting this year are not as robust as they appear because of costs put off during the recession, like funding for Medicaid and pension systems.

headline.main: Surpluses Help, but Fiscal Woes for States Go On
headline.print_headline: Surpluses Help, But Fiscal Woes For States Go On
